awd_titl_txt: P-adic Methods in the Arithmetic and Geometry of Shimura Varieties
awd_abstract_narration:
The main purpose of this project is to bring to bear new methods for the PI's ongoing study of certain spaces defined by polynomial equations, which have proven to be fruitful ground for exploiting relationships between two disparate kinds of objects, one from the world of analysis, involving infinite sums, and the other from the world of geometry, involving the knowledge of how certain subspaces meet each other. The path to such relationships, starting from the classical work of Gross-Zagier, has greatly enhanced our understanding of elliptic curve cryptography.

The goal of this project is to study the intersection theory of higher codimension cycles on orthogonal Shimura varieties with an eye towards Kudla's conjectures relating intersection numbers with central derivatives of certain Eisenstein series. This will involve a two-pronged approach: First, to define suitable generating series of such cycles on integral models, and to show their modularity. Second, to develop a p-adic analytic theory of Ekedahl-Oort strata, which can be combined with recent advances in a rigid analytic intersection theory to compute the relevant local intersections.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Arithmetic geometry is the study of geometric spaces that can be defined in terms of polynomial equations with integer entries. An important collection of such spaces is given by what are called 'Shimura varieties', whose topology and arithmetic intertwine to witness many instances of the Langlands program. This program relates representation theory to the arithmetic of the integers in a fundamental way.

The goal of this project was to make progress on a different kind of relationship along these lines. It concerns an extensive web of conjectures by Steve Kudla on an intriguing connection between certain special subspaces or 'cycles' on some Shimura varieties and objects in representation theory. In the case of interest here, these latter objects are Eisenstein series, which are infinite sums of functions of arithmetic interest. They can be expressed as superpositions of wave functions---this is caled a Fourier expansion---and Kudla conjectured that the conribution of each wave function---called a Fourier coefficient---is related to intersection numbers between special cycles on Shimura varieties, which essentially measure the number of points at which the cycles intersect each other. This story has a long and storied history, going back to the seminal work of Hirzebruch-Zagier in the 70s and of Gross-Kohnen-Zagier soon after.

In this project, we contributed to this circle of ideas, by showing that the intersection numbers of cycles come very close to being Fourier coefficients of a modular form (a more general kind of object that includes Eisenstein series as a special case). These results can be found in the preprint 'Kudla's modularity conjecture on integral models of orthogonal Shimura varieties'.
